title: Life-changing drug headed for PBS | Gold Coast Bulletin
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search Use keywords to search content on this website Drug game-changer for thousands suffering from cystic fibrosis headed for the PBS February 5, 2017 4:00am LANAI SCARR EXCLUSIVE Jude David is a little boy who will benefit greatly from having a new treatment for cystic fibrosis listed on the PBS. Picture: Lindy Lawler AUSTRALIA’S youngest cystic fibrosis sufferers will this week get a massive reprieve when the government lists a life changing medication on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. 
News Corp Australia understands Health Minister Greg Hunt will this week approve the drug Kalydeco on the PBS for 2-5 year-olds. 
The medication will be listed from May with the government in negotiations with drug manufacturer Vertex about how to best to ease the burden on families until then. 
Families will only have to pay as low as $6.30 per script as opposed to $300,000 a year to access the drug. 
The listing comes after News Corp Australia started making calls about the issue amid increasing pressure on the government from sufferers and the federal opposition. 
It will mean the nation’s littlest sufferers of the life-shortening chronic illness will have a shot at a normal life with the drug one of the first in the world to address the underlying causes of CF rather than simply its symptoms. 
Sufferers will go from taking 60 to 80 tablets a day in the worst circumstances, to as few as 10 tablets a day. 
However, more than 1000 Australians over the age of 12 with a different mutation of the illness will still be left waiting for their shot at a normal life with the drug Orkambi yet to be listed on the PBS. 
Cystic Fibrosis is the most common, genetically acquired, life-shortening chronic illness affecting young Australians. 
Those with the illness develop an abnormal amount of thick, sticky mucus in the lungs and digestive system, trapping bacteria and leading to infections which result in irreversible damage. 
There is no cure and sufferers get progressively worse from birth. The average age of deaths from CF is 28. 
Michele Adair, CF Australia spokesperson and CEO of CFNSW said listing Kalydeco on the PBS for 2-5 year-olds would be a “game-changer”. 
The medication is currently listed for kids from the age of six, however often by that stage irreversible damage has already occurred, shaving years off their lives. 
“Often people with cystic fibrosis have to take between 60 to 80 tablets a day, they spend an hour or more inhaling up to four different antibiotics or other treatments and up to two hours a day in physio,” Ms Adair told News Corp Australia. 
“These drugs (Kalydeco and Orkambi) completely change that. As well as having significant health benefits they also result in fewer hospitalisations which reduces the cost burden for all. 
“There are just no words for how much this would help CF sufferers.” 
Currently patients who need Orkambi either have to take part in a clinical trial or pay $260,000 a year for access to the drug. 
Opposition health spokeswoman Catherine King said Labor was prepared to work with the government to do whatever it could to help alleviate the financial burden for sufferers and get them the lifesaving drugs they needed. 
“I can only imagine the distress of families in this situation,” Ms King said. 
“That’s why Labor is prepared to work with the Government in any way we can on this issue. As a priority we urge the government to work with the manufacturer and resolve outstanding issues as soon as possible.” 
Olivia Wood, 17, is just about to start her HSC but battles daily with cystic fibrosis. 
The Sydney teen attends hospital for 2-3 week stints at least four times a year to manage her illness. 
She takes more than 30 tablets a day and has done since a toddler. 
“Mum used to have to put them in apple sauce as that was the only way I would eat them,” Ms Wood told News Corp Australia. 
Having access to Orkambi would more than halve the number of tablets Ms Wood takes each day and would allow her to achieve her dreams of working as a chef or in hospitality. Her life would be full and long. 
“Having this drug would mean not coming into hospital as often and I could actually enjoy my life,” she said. 
Families and CF sufferers will on Tuesday travel to Canberra for a planned rally to highlight the need for Orkambi to be listed on the PBS. 
Caron David, 39, told News Corp Australia she cries every day for her son Jude, 2. 
The central coast mother and her husband Matthew, 41, had their lives ripped apart when at just five-weeks-old Jude was confirmed to have cystic fibrosis. 
After six years of IVF, Jude was their little miracle. 
Ms David said she would do anything to alleviate his suffering. 
Jude has to have physio three times a day, take oral vitamins and dozens of pills a week. 
“Having Kalydeco on the PBS will give my son a shot at a normal life,” she said. 
“It will allow him to get a job, to fall in love and do all the normal things to have a full and happy life. 
“This is an investment in our future. Putting this drug on the PBS is not a cost with no return. It will allow those who benefit from it to be productive members of society. My son won’t be a strain on the government or hospital system, he’ll be able to work and contribute.” More Local News
